Freeman had bought the film rights to John Carlin's book on which the film is based.{{cite news|last=Keller|first=Bill|title=Entering the Scrum|date=August 15, 2008|work=The New York Times|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/17/books/review/Keller-t.html|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5x9EZJdD0|archivedate=March 12, 2011}} The film met with generally positive reviews; Roger Ebert gave it three and a half stars and described it as a "very good film... with moments evoking great emotion",{{cite news|title=Invictus|url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20091209/REVIEWS/912099994|work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]|last=Ebert|first=Roger|authorlink=Roger Ebert|date=December 9, 2009|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5x9EHZO6u|archivedate=March 12, 2011}} while ''Variety''{{'}}s Todd McCarthy wrote, "Inspirational on the face of it, Clint Eastwood's film has a predictable trajectory, but every scene brims with surprising details that accumulate into a rich fabric of history, cultural impressions and emotion."{{cite news|title=Invictus|url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117941681.html?categoryid=31&cs=1|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|last=McCarthy|first=Todd|date=November 27, 2009|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5x9EMigMz|archivedate=March 12, 2011}} Eastwood was nominated for [[Golden Globe Award for Best Director|Best Director]] at the [[67th Golden Globe Awards]]. ===2010s=== {{quote box|width=30em|bgcolor=#c6dbf7|align=right|quote="Everybody wonders why I continue working at this stage. I keep working because there's always new stories. ... And as long as people want me to tell them, I'll be there doing them."|source=âEastwood, reflecting on his later career{{cite video|title=The Eastwood Factor (Extended Edition)|medium=DVD|publisher=[[Warner Home Video]]|time=1:26:15|date=June 1, 2010}}}} In 2010, Eastwood directed the drama ''[[Hereafter (film)|Hereafter]]'', again working with Damon, who portrayed a psychic. The film had its world premiere on September 12, 2010 at the [[2010 Toronto International Film Festival]] and was given a limited release on October 15, 2010.{{cite news|last=Punter|first=Jennie|title=Eastwood, Boyle among new Toronto entries|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118023009.html?categoryId=13&cs=1|date=August 17, 2010|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Reed Business Information]]|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5vePTu6Dn|archivedate=January 10, 2011}}{{cite news|last=Mercer|first=Benjamin|url=http://www.theatlantic.com/culture/archive/2010/10/eastwoods-hereafter-matt-damon-shines-despite-schmaltz/64236/|title=Eastwood's 'Hereafter': Matt Damon Shines, Despite Schmaltz|work=[[The Atlantic]]|date=October 11, 2010|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5vePm3J0V|archivedate=January 10, 2011}} ''Hereafter'' received mixed reviews from critics, with the consensus at [[Rotten Tomatoes]] being, "Despite a thought-provoking premise and Clint Eastwood's typical flair as director, ''Hereafter'' fails to generate much compelling drama, straddling the line between poignant sentimentality and hokey tedium."{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/hereafter/|title=Hereafter Movie Reviews, Pictures â Rotten Tomatoes|work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|accessdate=October 30, 2010}} In the same year, Eastwood served as executive producer for a [[Turner Classic Movies]] (TCM) documentary about jazz pianist [[Dave Brubeck]], ''[[Dave Brubeck: In His Own Sweet Way]]'', to commemorate Brubeck's 90th birthday.{{cite news|last=Mergner|first=Lee|date=November 29, 2010|url=http://jazztimes.com/articles/26871-in-dave-brubeck-s-own-sweet-way|title=In Dave Brubeck's Own Sweet Way|work=[[JazzTimes]]|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5vixgEhO4|archivedate=January 13, 2011}} Eastwood directed the 2011 biopic of [[J. Edgar Hoover]], ''[[J. Edgar]]'', focusing on the former FBI director's scandalous career and controversial private life. It starred [[Leonardo DiCaprio]] as Hoover,{{cite news|last=Rosenberg|first=Adam|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1641867/20100618/story.jhtml|title=Leonardo DiCaprio To Star In J. Edgar Hoover Biopic|publisher=[[MTV.com]]|date=June 18, 2010|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5vvv3yla4|archivedate=January 22, 2011}} [[Armie Hammer]] as [[Clyde Tolson]], and [[Damon Herriman]] as [[Bruno Hauptmann]]. In January 2011, it was announced that Eastwood is in talks to direct [[BeyoncÃ© Knowles]] in a third remake of the [[List of American films of 1937|1937 film]] ''[[A Star Is Born (1937 film)|A Star Is Born]]''.{{cite news|last=Magrath|first=Andrea|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1349280/Beyonce-Clint-Eastwood-team-A-Star-Is-Born-remake.html|title=A Star Is Born... again: Clint Eastwood in talks to direct Beyonce in yet another remake of Hollywood classic|work=[[Daily Mail]]|date=January 21, 2011|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5vvubxGeM|archivedate=January 22, 2011|location=London}} Production has been delayed due to the pregnancy of Knowles. In October 2011, ''Entertainment Weekly'' indicated that Eastwood was in talks to star in a baseball drama where he would play a veteran baseball scout who travels with his daughter for a final scouting trip. [[Robert Lorenz]], who worked with Eastwood as an assistant director on a few of his films, is in talks to direct the film.{{cite news|last=Breznican|first=Anthony|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2011/10/05/clint-eastwood-may-act-again-in-baseball-drama-breaking/|title=Clint Eastwood may act again in baseball drama -- Breaking|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=October 5, 2011|archivedate=October 5, 2011|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/62FABoBay}} ===Directing style=== Beginning with the thriller ''Play Misty for Me'', Eastwood has directed over 30 films in his career; including westerns, action films, and dramas. From the very early days of his career, Eastwood had been frustrated by directors insisting that scenes be re-shot multiple times and perfected, and when he began as a director in 1971, he made a conscious attempt to avoid any aspects of directing he had been indifferent to as an actor. As a result, Eastwood is renowned for his efficient film directing and to reduce filming time and to keep budgets under control. Eastwood usually avoids actors rehearsing and prefers most scenes to be completed on the first take.Munn, p. 160Kapsis and Coblentz, pp. 196â197 (interviewer Peter Biskind) In preparation for filming Eastwood rarely uses [[storyboard]]s for developing the layout of a shooting schedule.Kapsis and Coblentz, p. 65 (interviewer Ric Gentry)Kapsis and Coblentz, p. 173 (interviewer Denise Abbott)Kapsis and Coblentz, p. 235 (interviewer Pascal MÃ©rigeau) He also attempts to reduce script background details on characters to allow the audience to become more involved in the film,Kapsis and Coblentz, pp. 67â68 (interviewer Ric Gentry) considering their imagination a requirement for a film that connects with viewers.Kapsis and Coblentz, p. 91 (interviewer David Thomson) Eastwood has indicated that he lays out a film's plot to provide the audience with necessary details, but not "so much that it insults their intelligence."Kapsis and Coblentz, p. 60 (interviewer Ric Gentry)According to ''Life'' magazine, "Eastwood's style is to shoot first and act afterward. He etches his characters virtually without words. He has developed the art of underplaying to the point that anyone around him who so much as flinches looks hammily histrionic."{{cite book|last=Fayard|first=Judy|work=[[Life (magazine)|Life]]|title=Who can stand 32,580 seconds of Clint Eastwood?|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=OEAEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA44|accessdate=March 8, 2011|date=July 23, 1971|publisher=[[Time Inc.]]|page=46|id={{ISSN|00243019}}}} Interviewers Richard Thompson and Tim Hunter note that Eastwood's films are "superbly paced: unhurried; cool; and [give] a strong sense of real time, regardless of the speed of the narrative"Kapsis and Coblentz, p. 45 (interviewers Richard Thompson and Tim Hunter) while Ric Gentry considers Eastwood's pacing to be "unrushed and relaxed".Kapsis and Coblentz, p. 71 (interviewer Ric Gentry) Many of Eastwood's films rely on low lighting to give his films a [[Film noir|"noir-ish"]] feel.Kapsis and Coblentz, p. 143 (interviewer Milan PavoliÄ) Reviewers have pointed out that the majority of his films are based on the male point-of-view, although female characters typically have strong roles as both heroes and villains.Kapsis and Coblentz, p. 119 (interviewer Tim Cahill)Kapsis and Coblentz, p. 190 (interviewer Henri BÃ©har)Munn, p. 72 ==Politics== {{main|Political life of Clint Eastwood}} {{double image|right|ClintEastwoodReagan.jpg|220|Clint Eastwood DOI 1675.jpg|150|Left: Eastwood with President [[Ronald Reagan]] and [[Lou Gossett, Jr.]] in July 1987
Right: Eastwood as a a spokesman for [[Take Pride in America]] in 2005}} Eastwood registered as a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] to vote for [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]] in 1952 and later supported [[Richard Nixon]]'s [[United States presidential election, 1968|1968]] and [[United States presidential election, 1972|1972]] presidential campaigns. However, he later criticized Nixon's handling of the [[Vietnam War]] and his morality during [[Watergate]].Eliot, p. 115{{cite web|url=http://www.playboy.com/articles/clint-eastwood-1974-playboy-interview/index.html|title=Clint Eastwood: 1974 Playboy Interview|work=[[Playboy Magazine]]|date=February 1974|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5vxsTt7uJ|archivedate=January 23, 2011}} He expressed his disapproval of America's wars in [[Korean War|Korea]] (1950–1953), Vietnam (1964–1973), and [[Iraq War|Iraq]] (2003–2011), believing that the United States should not be overly militaristic or play the role of global policeman. He considers himself too individualistic to be either right-wing or left-wing, describing himself as a "political nothing" and a moderate in 1974 and a [[libertarianism|libertarian]] in 1997.{{cite web|url=http://www.playboy.com/articles/clint-eastwood-1997-playboy%20interview/|title=Clint Eastwood: 1997 Playboy Interview|work=[[Playboy Magazine]]|date=March 1997|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w6fYSuHU|archivedate=January 29, 2011}} Eastwood has stated that while he does not see himself as conservative, he is not an "ultra-leftist" either. At times he has supported [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrats]] in California, including Representative [[Sam Farr]] in 2002 and Governor [[Gray Davis]] in 2003.{{cite news|last=Cooper|first=Marc|url=http://www.thenation.com/article/left-coast-notes-3|title=Left Coast Notes|work=[[The Nation]]|date=May 8, 2003|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5vxsipPfq|archivedate=January 23, 2011}} A longtime [[libertarian]] on social issues, Eastwood has stated that he is pro-choice on abortion.{{cite web|url=http://www.playboy.com/articles/clint-eastwood-1997-playboy%20interview/index.html|title=Clint Eastwood: 1997 Playboy Interview|work=[[Playboy]]|date=March 1997|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5vxsmHBb6|archivedate=January 23, 2011}} He has endorsed the notion of allowing gays to marry{{cite news|title=American Icon series â Clint Eastwood|last=McCafferty|first=Dennis|work=[[USA Weekend]]|date=January 25, 2004}} and contributed to groups supporting the [[Equal Rights Amendment]] for women.Schickel, p. 380 [[File:ClintEastwood6.jpg|thumb|left|Eastwood outdoors at a Take Pride in America event.]] As a politician Eastwood has made successful forays into both local and state government. In April 1986 he was elected mayor for one term in his home town of [[Carmel-by-the-Sea, California]] â a small, wealthy town and artist community on the [[Monterey Peninsula]].Eliot, p. 227 During his term he tended towards supporting small business interests and advocating environmental protection.{{cite book|title=The Economist|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=IeftAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=January 16, 2011|year=1986|publisher=The Economist Newspaper Ltd.}} In 2001 Eastwood was appointed to the California State Park and Recreation Commission by Governor Davis,{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2008-03-20-schwarzeneggar-firings_N.htm|title='Terminator' fires Clint Eastwood, Shriver|work=[[USA Today]]|date=March 20, 2008|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5vcltydlv|archivedate=January 9, 2011}} then reappointed in 2004 by Governor [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]]. As the vice chairman of the commission, in 2005 along with chairman [[Bobby Shriver]], he led the movement opposed to a six-lane {{convert|16|mi|km|sing=on}} extension of [[California State Route 241]], a toll road that would cut through [[San Onofre State Beach]]. Eastwood and Shriver supported a 2006 lawsuit to block the toll road and urged the [[California Coastal Commission]] to reject the project, which it duly did in February 2008.{{cite news|last=Young|first=Samantha|url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/state/20080320-1635-schwarzenegger-parks.html|work=[[San Diego Union Tribune]]|title=Schwarzenegger removes his brother-in-law and Clint Eastwood from Calif. parks panel|date=March 20, 2008|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5uumanMoa|archivedate=December 11, 2010}} In March 2008 Eastwood and Shriver's non-reappointment to the commission on the expiry of their terms prompted the [[Natural Resources Defense Council]] (NDRC) to request a legislative investigation into the decision.{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/state/20080322-1416-ca-schwarzenegger-parkscommission.html|work=[[San Diego Union Tribune]]|title=Group wants probe into governor's removal of Eastwood, Shriver|date=March 22, 2008|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5uumlK7Ky|archivedate=December 11, 2010}} Governor Schwarzenegger appointed Eastwood to the [[California Film Commission]] in April 2004.{{cite news|title=Schwarzenegger to boost Hollywood|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/3631261.stm|publisher=BBC News|date=April 16, 2004|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5vclQP3k8|archivedate=January 9, 2011}} He has also acted as a spokesman for [[Take Pride in America]], an agency of the [[United States Department of the Interior]] which advocates taking responsibility for natural, cultural, and historic resources.{{cite book|title=Go Ahead. Make His Day|work=Boys' Life|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=YvwDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA15|accessdate=January 23, 2011|date=June 2005|publisher=[[Boy Scouts of America]]|page=15|id={{ISSN|00068608}}}} During the [[2008 United States Presidential Election]] Eastwood endorsed [[John McCain]], whom he has known since 1973, but nevertheless wished [[Barack Obama]] well upon his subsequent victory.{{cite news|last=Aguilar|first=Lou|title=Real Men Vote for McCain|work=[[National Review]]|date=July 18, 2008|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/articles/225026/real-men-vote-mccain/lou-aguilar#more|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5uumBVFUt|archivedate=December 11, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/.../clint-eastwood-on-gran-to_n_149862.html |title=Clint Eastwood On "Gran Torino," Getting Old And The Spike Lee Feud|publisher=Huffingtonpost.com|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5uumHDTD8|archivedate=December 11, 2010}} In August 2010 Eastwood wrote to the British [[Chancellor of the Exchequer]] [[George Osborne]] to protest the decision to close the [[UK Film Council]], warning that the closure could result in fewer foreign production companies choosing to work in the UK.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-10911948|title=Clint Eastwood writes plea to save UK Film Council|publisher=BBC News|date=August 9, 2010|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5vxrz1mNV|archivedate=January 23, 2011}} ==Personal life== {{main|Personal life of Clint Eastwood}} ===Relationships=== Eastwood has fathered at least seven children by five different women and has been described as a "serial womanizer". According to biographers Eastwood has always had a strong sexual appetite and particularly so during the 1970s. He has had affairs with many women including actresses [[Catherine Deneuve]], [[Peggy Lipton]], [[Jean Seberg]], [[Kay Lenz]], [[Jamie Rose]], [[Inger Stevens]], [[Jo Ann Harris]], [[Jill Banner]], casting director Jane Brolin, script analyst Megan Rose, and swimming champion Anita Lhoest.Eliot, p. 211 Eastwood married Maggie Johnson on December 19, 1953, six months after they met on a blind date.Munn, p. 19 While separated from Johnson, Eastwood had an affair with dancer Roxanne Tunis, with whom he had his first child, Kimber (born June 17, 1964); he did not publicly acknowledge her until 1996.Eliot, p. 68 After a reconciliation, he had two children with Johnson: [[Kyle Eastwood]] (born May 19, 1968) and [[Alison Eastwood]] (born May 22, 1972). Eastwood filed for divorce in 1979 after a long separation, but the $25 million (US${{Formatprice|{{Inflation|US|25000000|1984|r=2}}}} in {{CURRENTYEAR}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) divorce settlement was not finalized until May 1984.Eliot, p. 176Eliot, p. 6 Eastwood entered a relationship with actress [[Sondra Locke]] in 1975, and they lived together for fourteen years despite the fact that she remained married (in name only) to her gay husband, Gordon Anderson.http://www.annonline.com/interviews/971111/biography.html{{cite book|last=Locke|first=Sondra|title= The good, the bad, and the very ugly: a Hollywood journey|publisher= Morrow|year= 1997|ISBN=9780688154622|page=45}} They co-starred in six films together: ''[[The Outlaw Josey Wales]]'', ''[[The Gauntlet (film)|The Gauntlet]]'', ''[[Every Which Way but Loose (film)|Every Which Way but Loose]]'', ''[[Bronco Billy]]'', ''[[Any Which Way You Can]]'', and ''[[Sudden Impact]]''. Early on in the relationship, Locke had two abortions and a subsequent [[tubal ligation]].Eliot, p. 193{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|title=Sondra Locke Suing Clint Eastwood|work=[[Sun Journal (Lewiston)|Lewiston Journal]]|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=H70gAAAAIBAJ&sjid=sWkFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4573%2C3414437|date=April 28, 1989|accessdate=April 29, 2010}} The couple separated acrimoniously in 1989; Locke filed a [[palimony]] suit against Eastwood after he changed the locks on the home they shared. She sued him a second time, for [[fraud]], regarding an alleged phony directing contract he gave her in settlement of the first lawsuit.{{cite news|last=O'Neill|first=Ann W.|title=Sondra Locke Suing Clint Eastwood|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/16576835.html?dids=16576835:16576835&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Sep+18%2C+1996&author=&pub=Los+Angeles+Times+%28pre-1997+Fulltext%29&desc=Eastwood+Denies+Fraud+in+Film+Deal+for+Former+Lover&pqatl=google|format=Fee required|date=September 18, 1996|accessdate=April 29, 2010}} Locke and Eastwood went on to resolve the dispute with a non-public settlement in 1999.{{cite news|last=Huffaker|first=Donna|title=Eastwood's Ex Settles With Warner Bros.|work=[[Los Angeles Daily News]]|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-83612488.html|format=Fee required|publisher=[[Highbeam Research]]|date=May 25, 1999|accessdate=April 29, 2010}} Her memoir ''The Good, the Bad, and the Very Ugly'' includes a harrowing account of their years together.http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,290016,00.html During his cohabitation with Locke, Eastwood had an affair with flight attendant Jacelyn Reeves. According to biographers they met at the premiere of ''Pale Rider'' where they conceived a son, [[Scott Eastwood|Scott Reeves]] (born March 21, 1986).Eliot, p. 226 They also had a daughter, Kathryn Reeves (born February 2, 1988), although neither of them were publicly acknowledged until years later.Eliot, p. 236 Kathryn served as [[Miss Golden Globe]] at the [[62nd Golden Globe Awards|2005 ceremony]] where she presented Eastwood with an award for ''Million Dollar Baby''.http://www.goldenglobes.org/miss_golden_globe/ In 1990 Eastwood began living with actress [[Frances Fisher]], whom he had met on the set of ''[[Pink Cadillac]]'' (1989).McGilligan, p. 434 They co-starred in ''[[Unforgiven]]'' and had a daughter, Francesca Fisher-Eastwood (born August 7, 1993).Eliot, p. 289 The couple ended their relationship in early 1995,McGilligan, p. 501 but remain friends and later appeared together in ''True Crime''. [[File:Clint and Dina Eastwood.jpg|thumb|right|Eastwood with wife [[Dina Eastwood|Dina]] in 2007]] Eastwood subsequently began dating [[Dina Eastwood|Dina Ruiz]], an anchorwoman 35 years his junior, whom he had first met when she interviewed him in 1993. They married on March 31, 1996, when Eastwood surprised her with a private ceremony at his home on the [[Shadow Creek Golf Course]] in Las Vegas.{{cite news|agency=[[Reuters]]|title=Clint's wife expecting|url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/thestar/access/18702402.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Sep+06%2C+1996&author=&pub=Toronto+Star&desc=Clint%27s+wife+expecting&pqatl=google|format=Fee required|work=[[Toronto Star]]|date=September 6, 1996|accessdate=March 7, 2011}} After their wedding, Dina commented "The fact that I am only the second woman he has married really touches me."Eliot, p.295 The couple has one daughter, Morgan Eastwood (born December 12, 1996). Eastwood has two grandchildren: Clinton (born 1984) and Graylen (born 1994), by Kimber and Kyle respectively.http://movies.yahoo.com/movie/contributor/1800019744/bio ===Leisure=== [[File:Hog Breaths Inn.jpg|thumb|The Hog's Breath Inn in Carmel, once owned by Eastwood]] Despite appearing to smoke in many of his films, Eastwood is a life-long non-smoker, has been conscious of his health and fitness since he was a teenager, and practices healthy eating and daily [[Transcendental Meditation]].McGilligan, p. 108Oates, p. 17{{cite news|last=Corliss|first= Richard|title=The Last Roundup|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date=August 10, 1992}} On July 21, 1970, Eastwood's father died unexpectedly of a [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]] at the age of 64. This profoundly altered Eastwood's lifestyle, encouraging him to adopt a vigorous health and exercise regime to ensure his longevity.McGilligan, p. 193 He abstained from hard liquor, although he still favored cold beer, and opened an old English-inspired pub called the Hog's Breath Inn in [[Carmel-by-the-Sea, California|Carmel-by-the-Sea]] in 1971.McGilligan, p. 204 Eastwood eventually sold the pub and now owns the Mission Ranch Hotel and Restaurant, also located in Carmel-by-the-Sea.{{cite web|url=http://www.missionranchcarmel.com/|title=Welcome to Mission Ranch|publisher=Mission Ranch Hotel and Restaurant|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5vckpm2bV|archivedate=January 9, 2011}} Eastwood is a keen golfer and owns the [[TehÃ ma Golf Club]]. He is also an investor in the world-renowned [[Pebble Beach Golf Links]] and donates his time every year to charitable causes at major tournaments.{{cite news|url=http://travel.latimes.com/articles/la-trw-pebblebeach14jun14|work=Los Angeles Times|title=California rejects Clint Eastwood's Monterey golf course|first1=Kenneth R.|last1=Weiss|date=June 14, 2007|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5vckyHPBy|archivedate=January 9, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.stroke.org.uk/media_centre/press_releases/clint_eastwood.html|title=Clint Eastwood "Makes Their Day"|publisher=The Stroke Association|date=March 18, 2002|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5vckuuApv|archivedate=January 9, 2011}} Eastwood was formerly a licensed pilot and often flew his helicopter to the studios to avoid traffic.Schickel, p. 25Eliot, p. 131 ===Music=== {{main|Discography of Clint Eastwood}} Eastwood has had a passion for music all his life. He particularly favors jazz and country and western music and is a pianist and composer.McGilligan, p. 114 Jazz has played an important role in Eastwood's life from a young age and, although he never made it as a professional musician, he passed on the influence to his son Kyle Eastwood, a successful jazz bassist and composer. Eastwood developed as a ragtime pianist early on and had originally intended to pursue a career in music by studying for a music theory degree after graduating from high school. In late 1959 he produced the album ''Cowboy Favorites'', released on the Cameo label. Eastwood has his own [[Warner Bros. Records]]-distributed imprint Malpaso Records, as part of his deal with Warner Brothers, which has released all of the scores of Eastwood's films from ''The Bridges of Madison County'' onward. Eastwood co-wrote "Why Should I Care" with [[Linda Thompson (singer)|Linda Thompson]] and [[Carole Bayer Sager]], which was recorded by [[Diana Krall]].{{cite news|title=Krall, Eastwood Team For 'crime'|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=AllBusiness.com|url=http://www.allbusiness.com/retail-trade/miscellaneous-retail-retail-stores-not/4607056-1.html|date=March 11, 1999|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5uunYzwbK|archivedate=December 11, 2010}} Eastwood composed the [[film score]]s of ''Mystic River'', ''[[Grace Is Gone (film)|Grace Is Gone]]'' (2007), ''[[Changeling (2008 film)|Changeling]]'', and ''[[J. Edgar]]'', and the original piano compositions for ''[[In the Line of Fire]]''. He also wrote and performed the song heard over the credits of ''Gran Torino''.{{cite news|last=Headlam|first=Bruce|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/12/14/movies/14head.html?_r=1|title=The Films Are for Him. Got That?|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=December 10, 2008|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5veOl9DiK|archivedate=January 10, 2011}} The music in ''Grace Is Gone'' received two [[Golden Globe Award|Golden Globe]] nominations by the [[Hollywood Foreign Press Association]] for the [[65th Golden Globe Awards]]. Eastwood was nominated for [[Golden Globe Award for Best Original Score|Best Original Score]], while the song "Grace is Gone" with music by Eastwood and lyrics by Carole Bayer Sager was nominated for [[Golden Globe Award for Best Original Song|Best Original Song]].{{cite web|url=http://www.goldenglobes.org/news/id/81 |title=Hollywood Foreign Press Association 2008 Golden Globe Awards For the Year Ended December 31, 2007|accessdate=January 19, 2011|date=December 13, 2007|publisher=goldenglobes.org|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20071214020838/http://www.goldenglobes.org/news/id/81|archivedate=2007}} It won the [[Satellite Award]] for Best Song at the [[Satellite Awards 2007|12th Satellite Awards]]. ''Changeling'' was nominated for Best Score at the 14th Critics' Choice Awards, [[Golden Globe Award for Best Original Score|Best Original Score]] at the [[66th Golden Globe Awards]], and Best Music at the 35th Saturn Awards. On September 22, 2007, Eastwood was awarded an honorary [[Doctor of Music]] degree from the [[Berklee College of Music]] at the [[Monterey Jazz Festival]], on which he serves as an active board member. Upon receiving the award he gave a speech claiming, "It's one of the great honors I'll cherish in this lifetime."{{cite web|title=Clint Eastwood Receives Berklee Degree at Monterey Jazz Festival (news release)|date=September 24, 2007|publisher=[[Berklee College of Music]]|url=http://www.berklee.edu/news/2007/09/0924.html|archivedate=December 11, 2010|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5uuo8sCXG}} ==Awards and honors== {{Main|List of awards and nominations received by Clint Eastwood|List of awards and nominations received by Clint Eastwood by film}} {| class="wikitable floatright" style="max-width: 26em;" |+ Academy Awards |- ! Year !! Award !! Film !! W/N |- | rowspan="3"|1992 || [[Academy Award for Best Director|Best Director]] || ''[[Unforgiven]]'' || style="text-align: center"|Won |- | [[Academy Award for Best Picture|Best Picture]] || ''Unforgiven'' || style="text-align: center"|Won |- | [[Academy Award for Best Actor|Best Actor]] || ''Unforgiven'' || Nominated |- | 1994 || colspan="2"|[[Irving G. Thalberg Memorial Award]] || style="text-align: center"|Won |- | rowspan="2"|2003 || Best Director || ''[[Mystic River (film)|Mystic River]]'' || Nominated |- | Best Picture || ''Mystic River'' || Nominated |- | rowspan="3"|2004 || Best Director || ''[[Million Dollar Baby]]'' || style="text-align: center"|Won |- | Best Picture || ''Million Dollar Baby'' || style="text-align: center"|Won |- | Best Actor || ''Million Dollar Baby'' || Nominated |- | rowspan="2"|2006 || Best Director || ''[[Letters from Iwo Jima]]'' || Nominated |- | Best Picture || ''Letters from Iwo Jima'' || Nominated |} Eastwood has been recognized with multiple awards and nominations for his work in film, television, and music. His widest reception has been in film work, for which he has received Academy Awards, [[Directors Guild of America Award]]s, [[Golden Globe Award]]s, and [[People's Choice Awards]], among others. Eastwood is one of only two people to have been twice nominated for Best Actor and Best Director for the same film (''Unforgiven'' and ''Million Dollar Baby'') the other being [[Warren Beatty]] (''[[Heaven Can Wait (1978 film)|Heaven Can Wait]]'' and ''[[Reds (film)|Reds]]''). Along with Beatty, [[Robert Redford]], [[Richard Attenborough]], [[Kevin Costner]], and [[Mel Gibson]], he is one of the few directors best known as an actor to win an Academy Award for directing. On February 27, 2005, he became one of only three living directors (along with [[MiloÅ¡ Forman]] and [[Francis Ford Coppola]]) to have directed two Best Picture winners.{{cite news|last=French|first=Philip|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/film/2007/feb/25/clinteastwood.oscars|title=Interview: Clint Eastwood, 'I figured I'd retire gradually, just ride off into the sunset ...'|work=[[The Observer]]|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''|date=February 25, 2007|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w8kkpugi|archivedate=January 30, 2011|location=London}} At age 74, he was also the oldest recipient of the Academy Award for Best Director. Eastwood has directed five actors in Academy Awardâwinning performances: [[Gene Hackman]] in ''Unforgiven'', [[Tim Robbins]] and [[Sean Penn]] in ''Mystic River'', and [[Morgan Freeman]] and [[Hilary Swank]] in ''Million Dollar Baby''. [[File:CAHoF Entrance.jpg|thumb|right|Clint Eastwood display in the entrance to the [[California Hall of Fame]]]] On August 22, 1984, Eastwood was honored at a ceremony at Grauman's Chinese theater to record his hand and footprints in cement.Eliot, p. 213 Eastwood received the AFI Life Achievement Award in 1996 and received an honorary degree from AFI in 2009. On December 6, 2006, California Governor [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]] and First Lady [[Maria Shriver]] inducted Eastwood into the [[California Hall of Fame]] located at [[The California Museum for History, Women, and the Arts]].{{cite news|last1=Matier|first1=Phillip |first2=Andrew |last2=Ross|title=Eastwood to share top billing in Hall of Fame|url=http://articles.sfgate.com/2006-12-06/bay-area/17325327_1_dirty-harry-academy-tests-police-academy|date=December 6, 2006|work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5veMvotcp|archivedate=January 10, 2011}} In early 2007, Eastwood was presented with the highest civilian distinction in France, [[LÃ©gion d'honneur]], at a ceremony in Paris. French President [[Jacques Chirac]] told Eastwood that he embodied "the best of Hollywood".{{cite news|title=Eastwood receives French honour|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/6371461.stm|date=February 17, 2007|publisher=BBC News|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5uuo2v0vq|archivedate=December 11, 2010}} In October 2009, he was honored by the [[LumiÃ¨re Award]] (in honor of the [[Auguste and Louis LumiÃ¨re|LumiÃ¨re Brothers]], inventors of the [[Cinematograph]]) during the first edition of the [[LumiÃ¨re Film Festival]] in [[Lyon]], France. This award honors his entire career and his major contribution to the 7th Art. In February 2010, Eastwood was recognized by [[President of the United States|President]] [[Barack Obama]] with an arts and humanities award. Obama described Eastwood's films as "essays in individuality, hard truths and the essence of what it means to be American."{{cite news|last=Simmons|first=Christine|title=Bob Dylan, Clint Eastwood get White House awards|url=http://www.usatoday.com/life/people/2010-02-25-white-house-awards_N.htm|date=February 25, 2010|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5voyzN8eE|archivedate=January 17, 2011|work=USA Today}} Eastwood has also been awarded at least three honorary degrees from universities and colleges, including an honorary degree from the [[University of the Pacific (United States)|University of the Pacific]] in 2006, an honorary Doctor of Humane Letters from the [[University of Southern California]] on May 27, 2007, and an honorary [[Doctor of Music]] degree from the [[Berklee College of Music]] at the [[Monterey Jazz Festival]] on September 22, 2007.{{cite news|last=Bowen|first=Rebecca|title=Berklee awards Clint Eastwood honorary doctorate|date=September 13, 2007|work=[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]]|url=http://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2007/09/berklee-awards-clint-eastwood-honorary-doctorate.html|archivedate=January 17, 2011|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5vowkQP5o}}{{cite news|title=An honorary Trojan|url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/1269513241.html?dids=1269513241:1269513241&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=May+12%2C+2007&author=&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&desc=An+honorary+Trojan&pqatl=google|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|format=Fee required|date=May 12, 2007|accessdate=January 17, 2011}} ==Filmography== {{Main|Clint Eastwood filmography}} Eastwood has contributed to over 50 films over his career as actor, director, producer, and composer. He has acted in several television series, most notably starring in ''[[Rawhide (TV series)|Rawhide]]''. He started directing in 1971 and made his debut as a producer in 1982 with ''[[Firefox (film)|Firefox]]'', though he had been functioning as uncredited producer on all of his Malpaso Company films since ''[[Hang 'Em High]]'' in 1968. Eastwood also has contributed music to his films, either through performing, writing, or composing. He has mainly starred in western, action, and drama films. According to the box office-revenue tracking website, [[Box Office Mojo]], films featuring Eastwood have grossed a total of more than US$1.68 billion domestically, with an average of $37 million per film.{{cite news|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/people/chart/?id=clinteastwood.htm|title=Clint Eastwood|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=January 16, 2011}} ==Notes== {{Reflist|colwidth=20em}} ==Bibliography== *{{cite book|last=Baker|first=Brian|title=Masculinity in Fiction and Film: Representing Men in Popular Genres, 1945â2000|year=2006|publisher=Continuum International Publishing Group|isbn=9780826486523}} *{{cite book|last=Baldwin|first=Louis|title=Turning Points: Pivotal Moments in the Careers of 83 Famous Figures|year=1999|publisher=McFarland|isbn=9780786406265}} *{{cite book|authors=Canby, Vincent;
